description: From Middle English fige, fygge (also fyke, from Old English fƒ´c, see fike), borrowed from Anglo-Norman figue, borrowed from Old French figue, from Old Occitan figa, from Vulgar Latin *fƒ´ca (‚Äúfig‚Äù), from Latin fƒ´cus (‚Äúfig tree‚Äù), from a pre-Indo European language, perhaps Phoenician ê§êê§Ç‚Äé (pg, literally ‚Äúripe fig‚Äù) (compare Biblical Hebrew ◊§÷∑÷º◊í÷∏÷º◊î‚Äé (pagg√¢, ‚Äúearly fallen fig‚Äù), Classical Syriac ‹¶‹ì‹ê‚Äé (paggƒÅ æ), dialectal Arabic ŸÅŸéÿ¨Ÿë‚Äé (fajj), ŸÅŸêÿ¨Ÿë‚Äé (fijj)). (Another Semitic root (compare Akkadian íà† (tƒ´ æu, literally ‚Äúfig‚Äù)) was borrowed into Ancient Greek as œÉ·ø¶Œ∫ŒøŒΩ (s√ªkon) (whence English sycophant; Boeotian œÑ·ø¶Œ∫ŒøŒΩ (t√ªkon)) and Armenian as ’©’∏÷Ç’¶ (t øuz).) The soap-making sense derives from the resemblance of the granulations in and texture of the soap to those of a fig. Doublet of fico.

entries.meaning: A fruit-bearing tree or shrub of the genus Ficus that is native mainly to the tropics.
The fruit of the fig tree, pear-shaped and containing many small seeds.
The value of a fig, practically nothing; a fico; a whit.
The Lady Finger banana, also known as the "fig banana". (Cultivar of Musa acuminata.)

verbs.description: fig (third-person singular simple present figs, present participle figging, simple past and past participle figged)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To insult with a fico, or contemptuous motion.
(obsolete) To put into the head of, as something useless or contemptible.
(soap-making, dated) To develop, or cause (a soap) to develop, white streaks or granulations. [mid-1800s to mid-1900s]
examples: For filling figged soaps silicate of potash is best adapted, as soda prevents in a measure the proper crystallization. [...] Artificially figged soap [...makes] a very close imitation of the naturally figged soap.

verbs.description: fig (third-person singular simple present figs, present participle figging, simple past and past participle figged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move suddenly or quickly; rove about.
(colloquial, dated) A person's figure; dress or appearance.

verbs.description: fig (third-person singular simple present figs, present participle figging, simple past and past participle figged)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dated, transitive) To dress; to get oneself up a certain way.
The piece of ginger root used in figging.

verbs.description: fig (third-person singular simple present figs, present participle figging, simple past and past participle figged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To insert a ginger root into the anus, vagina or urethra of (a horse): to perform figging upon; to feague, to feak.
